line: Produced by Andrew Sly
My
First Picture Book.
With
Thirty-six pages of pictures
Printed in colours by Kronheim.
London & New York:
George Routledge and Sons.
Transcriber's note:
The grouping of letters in the alphabet section and a few paragraph
breaks have been adjusted to accomodate image placement. There were
no illustrations for the letters J and X in the original.
Contents
My First Alphabet
The Little Old Woman who Lived in a Shoe
The Babes in the Wood
Little Bo-Peep
The History of Five Little Pigs
The History of Old Mother Goose and her Son Jack

THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Once on a time there was a Little Old Woman who lived in a Shoe. This

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: shoe stood near a great forest, and was so large that it served as a

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: house for the Old Lady and all her children, of which she had so many

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: that she did not know what to do with them.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: [Illustration: Old Woman with children and Shoe.]

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: But the Little Old Woman was very fond of her children, and they only

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: thought of the best way to please her. Strong-arm, the eldest, cut

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: down trees for firewood. Peter made baskets of wicker-work. Mark was

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: chief gardener. Lizzie milked the cow, and Jenny taught the younger

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: children to read.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Now this Little Old Woman had not always lived in a Shoe. She and

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: her family had once dwelt in a nice house covered with ivy, and her

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: husband was a wood-cutter, like Strong-arm. But there lived in a huge

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: castle beyond the forest, a fierce giant, who one day came and laid

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: their house in ruins with his club; after which he carried off the

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: poor wood-cutter to his castle beyond the forest. When the Little Old

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Woman came home, her house was in ruins and her husband was no where

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: to be seen.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: [Illustration: Giant holding Wood-cutter.]

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Night came on, and as the father did not return, the Old Lady and her

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: family went to search for him. When they came to that part of the

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: wood where the Giant had met their father, they saw an immense shoe.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: They spent a long time weeping and calling out for their father, but

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: met with no reply. Then the Old Lady thought that they had better

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: take shelter in the shoe until they could build a new house. So Peter

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: and Strong-arm put a roof to it, and cut a door, and turned it into a

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: dwelling. Here they all lived happily for many years, but the Little

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Old Lady never forgot her husband and his sad fate. Strong-arm, who

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: saw how wretched his mother often was about it, proposed to the next

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: eleven brothers that they should go with him and set their father

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: free from the Giant. Their mother knew the Giant's strength, and

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: would not hear of the attempt, as she feared they would be killed.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: But Strong-arm was not afraid. He bought a dozen sharp swords, and

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Peter made as many strong shields and helmets, as well as cross-bows

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: and iron-headed arrows. They were now quite ready; Strong-arm gave

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: the order to march, and they started for the forest. The next day

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: they came in sight of the Giant's Castle. Strong-arm, leaving his

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: brothers in a wood close by, strode boldly up to the entrance, and

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: seized the knocker. The door was opened by a funny little boy with a

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: large head, who kept grinning and laughing.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: [Illustration: Strong-arm and Boy with Large Head.]

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Strong-arm then walked boldly across the court-yard, and presently

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: met a page, who took off his hat and asked him what he wanted.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Strong-arm said he had come to liberate his father, who was kept a

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: prisoner by the Giant; on this the little man said he was sorry for

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: him, because the part of the castle in which his father was kept was

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: guarded by a large dragon. Strong-arm, nothing daunted, soon found

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: the monster, who was fast asleep, so he made short work of him by

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: sending his sword right through his heart; at which he jumped up,

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: uttering a loud scream, and made as if he would spring forward and

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: seize Strong-arm; but the good sword had done its work, and the

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: monster fell heavily on the ground, dead.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: [Illustration: Strong-arm killing Dragon.]

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Now the Giant, who had been drinking much wine, was fast asleep in a

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: remote part of the castle. Strong-arm had no sooner finished the

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Dragon, than up started the funny little boy who had opened the door.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: He led Strong-arm round to another part of the court-yard, where he

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: saw his poor father, who at once sprung to his feet, and embraced

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: him. Then Strong-arm called up his brothers, and when they had

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: embraced their father, they soon broke his chain and set him

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: free.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: We must now return to the Little Old Woman. After her sons had

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: started she gave way to the most bitter grief. While she was in this

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: state, an old witch came up to her, and said she would help her, as

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: she hated the Giant, and wished to kill him. The Old Witch then took

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: the little Old Lady on her broom, and they sailed off through the

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: air, straight to the Giant's castle.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: [Illustration: Witch and Lady on broom.]

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Now this old Witch had great power, and at once afflicted the Giant

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: with corns and tender feet. When he awoke from his sleep he was in

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: such pain that he could bear it no longer, so he thought he would go

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: in search of his missing shoe, which, like the other one he had in

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: his castle, was easy and large for his foot. When he came to the

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: spot where the Old Lady and her children lived, he saw his old shoe,

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: and with a laugh that shook the trees, he thrust his foot into it,

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: breaking through the roof that Strong-arm and Peter had put to it.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: The children, in great alarm, rushed about inside the shoe, and

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: frightened and trembling, scrambled through the door and the slits

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: which the Giant had formerly made for his corns. By this time the

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: witch and the Little Old Lady, as also Strong-arm, his eleven

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: brother and his father, were come up to the spot. Strong-arm and his

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: brothers shot their arrows at him till at last he fell wounded, when

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: Strong-arm went up to him and cut off his head. Then the father and

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: the Little Old Woman and all their children built a new house, and

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: lived happily ever afterwards.

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
line: [Illustration: Strong-arm cutting off Giant's head.]

Poem Title: THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.
THE LITTLE OLD WOMAN WHO LIVED IN A SHOE.

THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: A gentleman of good account

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: In Norfolk dwelt of late,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Whose wealth and riches did surmount

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Most men of his estate.

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Sore sick he was, and like to die,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: No help his life could save;

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: His wife by him as sick did lie,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: And both were near the grave.

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: No love between these two was lost:

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Each to the other kind;

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: In love they lived, in love they died,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: And left two babes behind.

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Now if the children chanced to die,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Ere they to age should come,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Their uncle should possess their wealth:

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: For so the will did run.

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: "Now brother," said the dying man,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: "Look to my children dear;

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Be good unto my boy and girl,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: No friend else have they here."

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: [Illustration: Babes and Uncle at death-bed.]

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Their parents being dead and gone,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: The children home he takes,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: And brings them both unto his house,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Where much of them he makes.

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: He had not kept these pretty babes

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: A twelvemonth and a day,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: When, for their wealth, he did devise

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: To make them both away.

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: He bargain'd with two ruffians bold,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Who were of savage mood,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: That they should take the children twain,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: And slay them in a wood.

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: They prate and prattle pleasantly

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: While riding on the way,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: To those their wicked uncle hired,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: These lovely babes to slay:

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: [Illustration: Babes and Ruffians on horse-back.]

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: So that the pretty speech they had,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Made the ruffians' heart relent;

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: And they that took the deed to do,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Full sorely did repent.

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Yet one of them, more hard of heart,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Did vow to do his charge,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Because the wretch that hired him

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Had paid him very large.

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: The other would not agree thereto,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: So here they fell at strife;

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: With one another they did fight,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: About the children's life:

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: And he that was of milder mood,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Did slay the other there,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Within an unfrequented wood;

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: The babes did quake for fear!

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: [Illustration: Ruffian being killed.]

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: He took the children by the hand,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: While they for bread complain:

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: "Stay here," said he, "I'll bring ye bread,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: When I do come again."

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: These pretty babes, with hand in hand,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Went wandering up and down;

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: But never more they saw the man,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Approaching from the town:

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: [Illustration: Babes wandering.]

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Thus wander'd these two pretty dears,

line: Till death did end their grief;

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: In one another's arms they died,

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Poor babes, past all relief:

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: No burial these innocents

Poem Title: THE BABES IN THE WOOD.
line: Of any man receives,

line: But robin red-breast lovingly

line: Did cover them with leaves.

line: The fellow that did take in hand

line: These children for to kill,

LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: LITTLE BO-PEEP.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: "Little Bo-Peep she lost her sheep

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: And didn't know where to find them.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: Let them alone, and they'll come home,

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: And bring their tails behind them!"

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: [Illustration: Bo-peep searching.]

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: So runs the Nursery Rhyme. Little Bo-Peep was a very nice little

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: girl. Her cheeks had a bloom on them like a lovely peach, and her

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: voice sounded like a sweet silver bell.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: But though Little Bo-Peep was as good as she was beautiful, she

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: sometimes met with misfortunes that made her very sad. Once, when she

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: lost her sheep, she was very doleful indeed. And this is how it

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: happened.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: One summer evening, when the sun was setting, Little Bo-Peep, who had

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: to rise very early in the morning, felt tired, and sat down on a bank

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: covered with daisies. Being very weary she soon fell fast asleep. Now

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: the Bell-wether of Bo-Peep's flock was a most stupid and stubborn

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: fellow. I dare say you know that all the sheep in a flock will follow

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: the Bell-wether, and that he always wears a bell round his neck. It

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: was a great pity, but the Bell-wether of Bo-Peep's flock was very

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: wild, and was much given to wander far away into the wood, where of

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: course the rest of the sheep would follow him.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: Finding Little Bo-Peep asleep, the tiresome fellow began by standing

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: on his hind legs and making a great bow to his shadow before him on

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: the grass. After this he whirled himself round like a top, shaking

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: his head all the time, and ringing his bell.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: [Illustration: Bo-Peep asleep; Bell-wether capering.]

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: Very soon the rest of the flock began to dance and caper too. And

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: when they had wheeled round their leader for a time, they ran off

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: after him with a bound into the wood. Away they went, till they were

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: quite tired out; and then they came to a stand-still, staring at their

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: leader with very blank faces. But the Bell-wether looked foolish

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: enough now, and did nothing but shake his head slowly and ring his

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: bell, which seemed to say quite clearly, "You are lost, you are

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: lost!"

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: When Little Bo-Peep awoke she found her sheep gone, and hardly

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: knowing what she did, she walked on and on, far into the wood. She

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: met some people with hoes and rakes in their hands, and asked them if

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: they had seen her sheep. But they only laughed at her, and said, No.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: One man was very cross, and threatened to beat her. At last she came

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: to a stile, on which an old Raven was perched. He looked so wise that

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: Little Bo-Peep asked him whether he had seen a flock of sheep. But he

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: only cried "Caw, caw, caw;" so Bo-Peep ran on again across the

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: fields.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: [Illustration: Bo-peep and Raven.]

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: She wandered on till night-fall, and being faint with hunger, was

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: very glad to see a light just before her. As she went on, she saw

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: that it shone from a cottage window. But when she came to the door,

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: it looked so dark and dismal that she was afraid to go in, and was

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: just going to run away, when a cross-looking old woman came out, and

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: dragged her into the cottage. She made her sit by the side of her

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: son, who was a very ugly youth with a great red face and red

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: hair.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: [Illustration: Bo-peep and ugly Youth.]

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: The old woman told him that she had brought Bo-Peep to be his wife,

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: so Bo-Peep, who did not like him at all, ran away while they were

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: asleep. But she did not know where to go, and gave herself up for

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: lost, when she heard something cry, "tu-whit--tu-whoo," in the

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: tree above her. It was a great owl, which began flapping its wings

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: with joy. Bo-Peep was frightened at first, but as the owl seemed very

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: kind, she followed it. It took her to a cottage were there was plenty

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: to eat and drink, and then, to Bo-Peep's great surprise, it began to

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: speak, and told her this story:--

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: "Know, dear Maiden," said the owl, "that I am the daughter of a King,

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: and was a lovely Princess; but I was changed into an owl by the old

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: woman at the cottage, because I would not marry her ugly son. But I

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: have heard the fairies say that one day a lovely maiden, who would

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: come into this wood to find her lost sheep, should be the means of my

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: gaining my own form again. You are that pretty maid, and I will take

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: you to a spot where you will find your sheep, but without their

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: tails. The elves will play with them for this night, but in the

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: morning every sheep will have its tail again, except the stupid

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: Bell-wether. You must then wave his tail three times over my head,

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: and I shall resume my shape again."

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: The owl flew off, and led Bo-Peep into the wood, and said, "Sleep,

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: maiden, I will watch." How long she was asleep she could not tell,

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: but the charmed spot was suddenly lighted up, and she saw the Queen

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: of the Fairies seated on a bank. The Queen said the sheep should be

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: punished for running away. She then saw all her sheep come trooping

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: into the place, and on every sheep there was an Elf, who held in his

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: hand a sheep's tail.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: [Illustration: Sheep and Elves.]

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: After riding them about for some time, and having great fun with

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: them, the mad sport ceased, and each Elf restored the tail to his

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: sheep--all but the Bell-wether's, which their leader hid in a

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: tree. When Bo-Peep awoke, she saw the owl flapping its wings as if

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: to remind her of her promise; so she fetched the tail, and waved it

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: three times over its head, when up started the most charming Princess

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: that ever was seen. The princess gave Bo-Peep a beautiful cottage,

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: and her sheep never ran away from their kind mistress again.

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
line: [Illustration: Bo-peep and Owl.]

Poem Title: LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
LITTLE BO-PEEP.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: [Illustration: Little Pig going to market.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: The Little Pig who Went to Market.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: There was once a family of Five Little Pigs, and Mrs. Pig, their

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: mother, loved them all very dearly. Some of these little pigs were

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: very good, and took a great deal of trouble to please her. The eldest

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: pig was so active and useful that he was called Mr. Pig. One day he

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: went to market with his cart full of vegetables, but Rusty, the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: donkey, began to show his bad temper before he had gone very far on

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: the road. All the coaxing and whipping would not make him move. So

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: Mr. Pig took him out of the shafts, and being very strong, drew the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: cart to market himself. When he got there, all the other pigs began

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: to laugh. But they did not laugh so loudly when Mr. Pig told them

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: all his struggles on the road. Mr. Pig lost no time in selling

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: his vegetables, and very soon after Rusty came trotting into the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: market-place, and as he now seemed willing to take his place in the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: cart, Mr. Pig started for home without delay. When he got there, he

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: told Mrs. Pig his story, and she called him her best and most worthy

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: son.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: [Illustration: Little Pig with mother.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: The Little Pig who Stayed at Home.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: This little pig very much wanted to go with his brother, but as he

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: was so mischievous that he could not be trusted far away, his mother

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: made him stay at home, and told him to keep a good fire while she

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: went out to the miller's to buy some flour. But as soon as he was

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: alone, instead of learning his lessons, he began to tease the poor

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: cat. Then he got the bellows, and cut the leather with a knife, so as

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: to see where the wind came from: and when he could not find this out,

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: he began to cry. After this he broke all his brother's toys; he

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: forced the drum-stick through the drum, he tore off the tail from the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: kite, and then pulled off the horse's head. And then he went to the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: cupboard and ate the jam. When Mrs. Pig came home, she sat down by

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: the fire, and being very tired, she soon fell asleep. No sooner had

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: she done so, than this bad little pig got a long handkerchief and

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: tied her in her chair. But soon she awoke and found out all the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: mischief that he had been doing. She saw at once the damage that he

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: had done to his brother's playthings. So she quickly brought out her

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: thickest and heaviest birch, and gave this naughty little pig such a

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: beating as he did not forget for a long time.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: [Illustration: Little Pig tying mother to chair.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: [Illustration: Little Pig in Dunce cap.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: The Little Pig who had Roast Beef.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: This little pig was a very good and careful fellow. He gave his

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: mother scarcely any trouble, and always took a pleasure in doing all

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: she bade him. Here you see him sitting down with clean hands and

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: face, to some nice roast beef, while his brother, the idle pig, who

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: is standing on a stool in the corner, with the dunce's cap on, has

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: none. He sat down and quietly learned his lesson, and asked his

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: mother to hear him repeat it. And this he did so well that Mrs. Pig

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: stroked him on the ears and forehead, and called him a good little

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: pig. After this he asked her to allow him to help her make tea.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: He brought everything she wanted, and lifted off the kettle from

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: the fire, without spilling a drop either on his toes or the carpet.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: By-and-bye he went out, after asking his mother's leave, to play with

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: his hoop. He had not gone far when he saw an old blind pig, who, with

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: his hat in his hand was crying at the loss of his dog; so he put his

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: hand in his pocket and found a halfpenny which he gave to the poor

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: old pig. It was for such thoughtful conduct as this that his mother

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: often gave this little pig roast beef. We now come to the little pig

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: who had none.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: [Illustration: Little Pig eating roast beef.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: The Little Pig who had None.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: This was a most obstinate and wilful little pig. His mother had set

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: him to learn his lesson, but no sooner had she gone out into the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: garden, than he tore his book into pieces. When his mother came back

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: he ran off into the streets to play with other idle little pigs like

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: himself. After this he quarrelled with one of the pigs and got a

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: sound thrashing. Being afraid to go home, he stayed out till it was

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: quite dark and caught a severe cold. So he was taken home and put to

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: bed, and had to take a lot of nasty physic.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: [Illustration: Little Pig running home.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: The Little Pig who Cried "Wee, wee," all the Way Home.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: This little pig went fishing. Now he had been told not to go into

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: Farmer Grumpey's grounds, who did not allow any one to fish in his

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: part of the river. But in spite of what he had been told, this

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: foolish little pig went there. He soon caught a very large fish, and

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: while he was trying to carry it home, Farmer Grumpey came running

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: along with his great whip. He quickly dropped the fish, but the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: farmer caught him, and as he laid his whip over his back for some

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: time, the little pig ran off, crying, "Wee, wee, wee," all the way

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
line: home.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF FIVE LITTLE PIGS.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: [Illustration: Mother Goose and family.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: Old Mother Goose lived in a cottage with her son Jack. Jack was a

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: very good lad, and although he was not handsome, he was good-tempered

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: and industrious, and this made him better-looking than half the other

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: boys. Old Mother Goose carried a long stick, she wore a high-crowned

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: hat, and high-heeled shoes, and her kerchief was as white as snow.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: Then there was the Gander that swam in the pond, and the Owl that sat

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: on the wall. So you see they formed a very happy family. But what a

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: fine strong fellow the Gander was! Whenever Old Mother Goose wanted

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: to take a journey, she would mount upon his broad strong back, and

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: away he would fly and carry her swiftly to any distance.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: [Illustration: Mother Goose and Gander flying.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: Now Old Mother Goose thought her Gander often looked sad and lonely;

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: so one day she sent Jack to market to buy the finest Goose he could

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: find. It was early in the morning when he started, and his way lay

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: through a wood. He was not afraid of robbers; so on he went, with his

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: Mother's great clothes-prop over his shoulder. The fresh morning air

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: caused Jack's spirits to rise. He left the road, and plunged into the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: thick of the wood, where he amused himself by leaping with his

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: clothes-prop till he found he had lost himself. After he had made

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: many attempts to find the path again, he heard a scream. He jumped up

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: and ran boldly towards the spot from which the sound came. Through an

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: opening in the trees he saw a young lady trying to get away from a

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: ruffian who wanted to steal her mantle. With one heavy blow of his

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: staff Jack sent the thief howling away, and then went back to the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: young lady, who was lying on the ground, crying.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: [Illustration: Jack and young lady.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: She soon dried her tears when she found that the robber had made off,

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: and thanked Jack for his help. The young lady told Jack that she was

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: the daughter of the Squire, who lived in the great white house on the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: hill-top. She knew the path out of the wood quite well, and when they

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: reached the border, she said that Jack must come soon to her father's

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: house, so that he might thank him for his noble conduct.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: When Jack was left alone, he made the best of his way to the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: market-place. He found little trouble in picking out the best Goose,

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: for when he got there he was very late, and there was but one left.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: But as it was a prime one, Jack bought it at once, and keeping to the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: road, made straight for home. At first the Goose objected to be

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: carried; and then, when she had walked along slowly and gravely for a

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: short time, she tried to fly away; so Jack seized her in his arms and

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: kept her there till he reached home.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: [Illustration: Jack carrying Goose.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: Old Mother Goose was greatly pleased when she saw what a fine bird

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: Jack had bought; and the Gander showed more joy than I can describe.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: And then they all lived very happily for a long time. But Jack would

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: often leave off work to dream of the lovely young lady whom he had

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: rescued in the forest, and soon began to sigh all day long. He

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: neglected the garden, cared no more for the Gander, and scarcely even

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: noticed the beautiful Goose. But one morning, as he was walking by

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: the pond, he saw both the Goose and the Gander making a great noise,

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: as though they were in the utmost glee. He went up to them and was

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: surprised to find on the bank a large golden egg. He ran with it to

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: his mother, who said, "Go to market, my son; sell your egg, and you

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: will soon be rich enough to pay a visit to the Squire." So to market

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: Jack went, and sold his golden egg; but the rogue who bought it of

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: him cheated him out of half his due. Then he dressed himself in his

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: finest clothes, and went up to the Squire's house. Two footmen stood

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: at the door, one looking very stout and saucy, and the other sleepy

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: and stupid.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: [Illustration: Jack and Footmen.]

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: When Jack asked to see the Squire, they laughed at him, and made

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: sport of his fine clothes; but Jack had wit enough to offer them each

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: a guinea, when they at once showed him to the Squire's room.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: Now the Squire, who was very rich, was also very proud and fat, and

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: scarcely turned his head to notice Jack; but when he showed him his

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: bag of gold, and asked for his daughter to be his bride, the Squire

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: flew into a rage, and ordered his servants to throw him into the

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: horse-pond. But this was not so easy to do, for Jack was strong and

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: active; and then the young lady come out and begged her father to

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: release him. This made Jack more deeply in love with her than ever,

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: and he went home determined to win her in spite of all. And well did

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: his wonderful Goose aid him in his design. Almost every morning she

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: would lay him a golden egg, and Jack, grown wiser, would no longer

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: sell them at half their value to the rogue who had before cheated

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: him. So Jack soon grew to be a richer man than the Squire himself.

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: His wealth became known to all the country round, and the Squire at

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: length consented to accept Jack as his son-in-law. Then Old Mother

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: Goose flew away into the woods on the back of her strong Gander,

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: leaving the cottage and the Goose to Jack and his bride, who lived

Poem Title: THE HISTORY OF OLD MOTHER GOOSE AND HER SON JACK.
line: happily ever afterwards.
